Activities should address climate change impacts which affect the viability of infrastructure and other resources at risk. Examples of planning activities can include vulnerability and risk assessments, design of expansion, protect-in-place or relocation activities; analysis of options; development of Tribal community mitigation efforts; design of emergency drills and exercises, and more.

Tribal Climate Adaptation programs provide support for climate resilient planning to help sustain Tribal ecosystems and natural and cultural resources, economies, infrastructure, human health, and safety. Funds may be used for trainings and workshops, vulnerability and risk assessment, supplementary monitoring for climate-related decision-making, scoping efforts, adaptation planning, travel support, ocean and coastal management planning, capacity building for adaptation planning, relocation, managed retreat, or protect-inplace assessment, planning, and design; and internships and youth engagement.

The purpose of this program is to provide financial and technical assistance to Tribes to increase the number of Tribal homes with zero-emission electricity. According to the IRA WHGB, eligible uses of funding are for (1) the provision of electricity to unelectrified Tribal homes through zero emissions energy systems; (2) transitioning electrified Tribal homes to zero-emissions energy systems; and (3) associated home repairs and retrofitting necessary to install the zero-emissions energy systems.

The purpose of this program is to support climate resilience planning to help sustain Tribal ecosystems and natural and cultural resources, economies, infrastructure, human health, and safety. Eligible uses include habitat restoration and adaptation activities, community directed relocation, and other activities.

program: Tribal Climate Resilience: Fish Hatchery Operations and Maintenance
summary: The goal of this program is to extend the life of 88 Tribal hatcheries across the nation and to support hatchery rearing and stocking programs. Eligible uses include fish hatchery maintenance and operations.

administration: Office of the Secretary Department-Wide Programs
program: Grants for States and Tribes for Voluntary Restoration
summary: The goal of this program is to provide grants to States, territories of the United States, and Tribes for implementing voluntary restoration projects on private or public lands. FY22 funding for this program was allocated across three primary areas: (1) Construction of captive bird propagation facilities for endangered bird species in Hawaii; (2) Landscape level biological control to reduce mosquito vector that causes avian malaria; (3) Supported the American the Beautiful Challenge to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation (NFWF), that support locally led ecosystem restoration projects that invest in watershed restoration, resilience, equitable access, workforce development, corridors and connectivity, and collaborative conservation.

administration: Office of the Secretary Department-Wide Programs
program: Grants for States and Tribes for Voluntary Restoration
summary: The goal of this program is to provide grants to States, territories of the United States, and Tribes for implementing voluntary restoration projects on private or public lands.

administration: Office of the Secretary Department-Wide Programs
program: Orphaned Well Site Plugging, Remediation, and Restoration
summary: Funding to administer a program for plugging wells on Federal land, and for issuing grants to States and Tribes on State, private, and Tribal land. Grants to States are available through three separate programs. Eligible uses for funding are: Inventory, site characterization, down-hole well plugging, surface remediation, removal of surface equipment, restoration of native species habitat impacted by orphaned wells and associated infrastructure, measurement and tracking of air and water pollution due to orphaned wells, and identification and remediation of disproportionate health and environmental impacts of orphaned wells on communities of color, low-income communities, and Tribal and indigenous communities.

administration: Office of the Secretary Department-Wide Programs
program: Direct Federal Spending for Revegetation of Mined Lands
summary: According to the IIJA WHGB, eligible projects include those which restore native vegetation and mitigate environmental hazards on mined Federal or non-Federal lands. DOI expects the funding to serve as an expansion or extension of existing DOI work in mine reclamation, mitigation and restoration, with a particular focus on restoring native vegetation, which would involve the National Seed Strategy.

administration: Office of the Secretary Department-Wide Programs
program: Good Neighbor Agreements with States and Tribes
summary: This program is for State and Tribes to implement restoration projects on Federal lands pursuant to "Good Neighbor Agreements." Funds may be available via agreements or contracts for “authorized restoration services” which include forest, rangeland, and watershed restoration services. ‘‘Good Neighbor Agreements’’ are cooperative agreements or contracts entered between the Federal government and a State, County, or Tribe to carry out authorized restoration services, allowing the US Forest Service and BLM to collaborate with these groups to plan and execute cross-jurisdictional restoration work. FY22 funded projects supported invasive species eradication in legacy disturbances, expansion of existing forestry agreements, wildlife habitat improvement, seasonal protections for wildlife and at-risk resources, and aquatic system restoration in areas impacted by legacy forest management. Also, BLM entered into a partnership with the Nevada Department of Wildlife, initiating a 5-year project to support future work to restore wildlife habitat and reduce wildfire risk.

administration: Office of the Secretary Department-Wide Programs
summary: The goal of this program is to develop and implement a new Native Hawaiian Climate Resilience Program that helps the Native Hawaiian Community cope with the effects of climate change by taking actions that maintain the integrity and identity of the Native Hawaiian Community while also building the capacity for adaptation, learning, and transformation. Eligible uses of funding may include climate change communication, education, and research; environmental hazard analysis; natural and cultural resource management and protection; socio-cultural communication, education, and research; adaptation planning; sustainability technical assistance; and access to related federal/state/county programs.

program: Climate Change Technical Assistance for Territories
summary: The goal of this program is to provide technical assistance the U.S. Insular Areas for climate change planning, mitigation, adaptation, and resilience, including American Samoa, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and Puerto Rico. The funds will support technical assistance to the U.S. Insular Areas for climate change planning, mitigation, adaptation, and resilience projects.

The goal of this program is to protect vulnerable communities from wildfire while preparing our communities and natural landscapes for a changing climate, through hazardous fuels management strategies, including mechanical thinning, precommercial thinning in young stands, timber harvesting, prescribed fire, and installation of control locations such as fuel breaks.

The goal of this program is to mitigate the damaging effects of wildfires and set landscapes on a path towards natural recovery and climate resilience through post-fire restoration and rehabilitation activities.

The Preparedness Program funds a range of actions that helps the Federal government prepare to respond to wildland fire. These include hiring people, training them, tracking their qualifications, and planning our wildland fire response ahead of time. It also provides for the purchasing of equipment for early wildfire detection, real-time monitoring and radios to support interoperability with interagency partners; financial assistance to local communities to purchase slip-on tanks; and increases in firefighter pay and other firefighter workforce reforms. Eligible uses: to increase the compensation and number of Federal wildland firefighters to build a permanent, year-round workforce; increase the Nation's preparedness to fight wildfires through satellite detection and the procurement and placement of early-warning wildfire detection and real-time monitoring equipment; improve radio interoperability; increase training of youth, including Native youth, to accelerate the pace and scale of hazardous fuels treatments; and to provide financial assistance to local governments to purchase slip-on tanker units to ready trucks for firefighting.

program: Wildfire Management - Joint Fire Science Program with Department of Agriculture
summary: The goal of this program is to support science and research on wildland fire management issues that mitigate wildfire risk. Eligible uses: Priority research to better understand wildfire risk and inform land practitioners on critical wildland fire management issues.
This program supports two major demonstrations of advanced nuclear reactors for commercial power generation.

This program establishes a carbon capture technology program for the development of six facilities to demonstrate transformational technologies that will significantly improve the efficiency, effectiveness, costs, emissions reductions, and environmental performance of coal and natural gas use, including in manufacturing and industrial facilities.

This program establishes a carbon capture technology program for the development of transformational technologies that will significantly improve the efficiency, effectiveness, costs, emissions reductions, and environmental performance of coal and natural gas use, including in manufacturing and industrial facilities.

program: Current and Former Mine Land Clean Energy Demonstrations
summary: This program aims to demonstrate the technical and economic viability of conducting clean energy projects on current and former mine lands. OCED will support up to five clean energy projects in geographically diverse regions, at least two of which shall be solar projects.

program: Electric Grid Upgrade Program - Ensuring Reliability & Resiliency
summary: This program aims to demonstrate innovative approaches to transmission, storage, and distribution infrastructure to harden and enhance resilience and reliability; and to demonstrate novel approaches to enhance regional grid resilience.

program: Energy Improvement in Rural and Remote Areas
summary: This program aims to provide financial assistance to improve, in rural or remote areas of the U.S., the resilience, safety, reliability, and availability of energy; and environmental protection from adverse impacts of energy generation.

program: Energy Storage Demonstration Pilot Grant Program
summary: This program supports first-of-a-kind energy storage system demonstration projects.
This program supports demonstration projects that test and validate technologies that reduce industrial emissions.

program: Long Duration Energy Storage Demonstration & Joint Initiative
summary: This program supports the demonstration of various long-duration energy storage technologies with regional diversity.

This program supports the development of 6-10 regional clean hydrogen hubs that demonstrably aid the achievement of the clean hydrogen production standards; demonstrate the production, processing, delivery, storage, and end use of clean hydrogen; and can be developed into a national clean hydrogen network to facilitate a clean hydrogen economy.

This program supports the development of four domestic regional direct air capture hubs, each of which will demonstrate a direct air capture technology or suite of technologies at commercial scale with the potential for capturing at least 1 million metric tons of CO2 annually from the atmosphere and storing that CO2 permanently in a geologic formation or through its conversion into products.

suboffice: Carbon Dioxide Transportation Infrastructure Finance and Innovation (CIFIA)
program: Carbon Dioxide Transportation Infrastructure Finance and Innovation (CIFIA)
summary: This program establishes the Carbon Dioxide Transportation Infrastructure Finance and Innovation (CIFIA) program, consisting of direct loans, loan guarantees, and/or grants to establish a regional network of large scale, common carrier carbon dioxide transportation infrastructure in the U.S. Carbon dioxide transportation projects supported by CIFIA will contribute to the reduction of carbon emissions by enhancing access to high-purity carbon dioxide for utilization or permanent sequestration and create new job opportunities with a free and fair choice to join a union.

This program aims to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned or occupied by low- income persons , reduce their total residential energy expenditures, and improve their health and safety, especially low-income persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, the handicapped, and children.

This program aims to increase the energy efficiency of dwellings owned or occupied by low- income persons, reduce their total residential energy expenditures, and improve their health and safety, especially low-income persons who are particularly vulnerable such as the elderly, the handicapped, and children.

This program provides grants to institutions of higher education to establish building training and assessment centers to educate and train building technicians and engineers on implementing modern building technologies.

This program provides grants to pay the Federal share of career skills training programs under which students concurrently receive classroom instruction and on-the- job training for the purpose of obtaining an industry-related certification to install energy efficient building technologies.

program: Energy Efficiency Revolving Loan Fund Capitalization Grants
summary: This program provides capitalization grants to States to establish a revolving loan fund under which the State shall provide loans and grants for energy efficiency audits, upgrades, and retrofits to increase energy efficiency and improve the comfort of buildings.

This program provides grants to eligible States to train individuals to conduct energy audits or surveys of commercial and residential buildings to build the clean energy workforce, save customers money on their energy bills, and reduce pollution from building energy use.

program: Energy Efficiency & Renewable Energy Improvements at Public Schools
summary: This program provides competitive grants to make energy efficiency, renewable energy, and alternative fueled vehicle upgrades and improvements at public schools.

program: Energy Efficiency Materials Pilot Program Grants
summary: This program provides grants to supply nonprofit buildings with energy-efficiency materials.

program: Energy Efficiency and Conservation Block Grant Program
summary: This program aims to assist States, local governments, and Tribes in implementing strategies to reduce energy use, reduce fossil fuel emissions, and improve energy efficiency.

This program provides funding to States to support electric transmission and distribution planning as well as planning activities and programs that help reduce carbon emissions in all sectors of the economy, including the transportation sector and accelerate the use of alternative transportation fuels and vehicle electrification.

program: Battery Manufacturing and Recycling Grants – Sec. 40207c
summary: This program provides grants to ensure that the United States has a viable domestic manufacturing and recycling capability to support a North American battery supply chain. Focus on demonstration projects, construction of commercial-scale facilities, and retrofit or retooling of existing facilities for battery component manufacturing, advanced battery manufacturing, and recycling.

program: Implementation Grants for Industrial Research & Assessment Centers – Sec. 40521.b1
summary: This program aims to fund upgrades for small- and medium-sized manufacturers that have been recommended in an assessment from an Industrial Assessment Center or Combined Heat and Power Technical Assistance Partnership.

program: Industrial Research and Assessment Centers – Sec. 40521.b2/b3
summary: This program provides funding for institutions of higher education, community colleges, trade schools, and union training programs to identify opportunities for optimizing energy efficiency and environmental performance at manufacturing and other industrial facilities.

program: Battery and Critical Mineral Recycling - State and Local Programs – Sec. 40207.f3
summary: This program aims to award grants to states and units of local government to assist in the establishment or enhancement of state battery collection, recycling, and reprocessing programs.

program: Battery and Critical Mineral Recycling - Retailers as Collection Points – Sec. 40207.f4
summary: This program aims to award grants to retailers that sell covered batteries or covered battery-containing products to establish and implement a system for acceptance and collection of covered batteries and covered battery-containing products for reuse, recycling, or proper disposal.

program: Advanced Energy Manufacturing and Recycling Grant Program
summary: This program supports manufacturing projects in communities that have experienced coal mine or coal-fired power plant closures. The Program will provide grants to small- and medium-sized manufacturers to build, expand, or re-equip facilities to produce or recycle property needed to support secure, resilient domestic clean energy supply chains. It also supports grants for manufacturers to install equipment that will substantially reduce greenhouse gas emissions manufacturing and industrial facilities.

This program provides rebates to industrial or manufacturing facility owners, commercial building owners, multifamily building owners, utilities, or energy service companies for the replacement of a qualified energy inefficient transformer with a qualified energy efficient transformer.

suboffice: Advanced Materials and Manufacturing Technologies Office
summary: This program provides a prize for recycling of lithium ion batteries and convene a task force on battery producer requirements.

suboffice: Advanced Materials and Manufacturing Technologies Office
program: Battery and Critical Mineral Recycling - Battery Recycling RD&D
summary: This program aims to to award grants for research, development, and demonstration projects to create innovative and practical approaches to increase the reuse and recycling of batteries.

suboffice: Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Technologies Office
program: Electric Drive Vehicle Battery Recycling and Second-Life Applications Program
summary: This program expands an existing program at the Department of Energy for research, development, and demonstration of electric vehicle battery recycling and second-life applications for vehicle batteries.

suboffice: Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Technologies Office
program: Clean Hydrogen Manufacturing Recycling Research, Development, and Demonstration Program
summary: This program provides Federal financial assistance to advance new clean hydrogen production, processing, delivery, storage, and use equipment manufacturing technologies and techniques.

suboffice: Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Technologies Office
summary: This program establishes a research, development, demonstration, and deployment program for purposes of commercialization to improve the efficiency, increase the durability, and reduce the cost of producing clean hydrogen using electrolyzers.

program: Pumped Storage Hydropower Wind and Solar Integration and System Reliability Initiative
summary: This program provides financial assistance to eligible entities to carry out project design, transmission studies, power market assessments, and permitting for a pumped storage hydropower project to facilitate the long-duration storage of intermittent renewable electricity.

program: Cost-effective Codes Implementation for Efficiency and Resilience
summary: This program aims to enable sustained, cost-effective implementation of updated building energy codes to save customers money on their energy bills.
This program aims to fund research, development, and demonstration activities to improve hydropower technologies.

program: Marine Energy Research, Development, and Demonstration
summary: This program aims to fund research, development, and demonstration activities to improve marine energy technologies.

This program provides financial assistance for the establishment of new National Marine Energy Centers and the continuation and expansion of the research, development, demonstration, testing, and commercial application activities at the existing Centers.
This program supports a program of research, development, demonstration, and commercial application for enhanced geothermal systems.
This program aims to fund research, development, demonstration, and commercialization activities to improve wind energy technologies.

program: Wind Energy Technology Manufacturing Recycling Research, Development, and Demonstration Program
summary: This program aims to award financial assistance to eligible entities for research, development, and demonstration, and commercialization projects to create innovative and practical approaches to increase the reuse and recycling of wind energy technologies.
This program aims to fund research, development, demonstration, and commercialization activities to improve solar energy technologies.

program: Advanced Solar Energy Manufacturing Initiative (New Solar Research & Development)
summary: This program aims to award financial assistance to eligible entities for research, development, demonstration, and commercialization projects to advance new solar energy manufacturing technologies and techniques.

program: Solar Energy Technology Recycling Research, Development, and Demonstration Program (Solar Recycling Research & Development)
summary: This program aims to award financial assistance to eligible entities for research, development, demonstration, and commercialization projects to create innovative and practical approaches to increase the reuse and recycling of solar energy technologies.

This program focuses on RD&D for new or expanded commercial large-scale carbon sequestration projects and associated carbon dioxide transport infrastructure, including funding for the feasibility, site characterization, permitting, and construction stages of project development.

program: Critical Material Innovation, Efficiency, and Alternatives Activities
summary: This program provides research, development, demonstration, and commercialization to develop alternatives to critical materials, to promote their efficient production and use, and ensure a long-term secure and sustainable supply of them.

program: Critical Material Supply Chain Research Facility
summary: This investment supports the construction of a critical materials supply chain research facility.

This program focuses on R&D to improve security of supply for rare earth elements, develop advanced separation technologies for the extraction and recovery of rare earth elements and other critical materials, and identifies any potential environmental or public health impacts that could arise from the recovery of rare earth elements.

program: Carbon Capture Technology Program (Front-End Engineering and Design Program Out Activities Under Carbon Capture Tech Program 962 Of EPA)
summary: This program expands DOE’s Carbon Capture Technology program to include a program for carbon dioxide transport infrastructure necessary to deploy carbon capture, conversion and geologic storage.
This program provides grants for state and local governments to procure and use products derived from captured carbon oxides.

program: Commercial Direct Air Capture Technology Prize Competitions
summary: This program supports large-scale DAC pilot and demonstration projects. Prizes will be awarded to projects that demonstrate the technical and commercial viability of technologies to reduce CO2 emissions from the atmosphere. Projects will also include rigorous life cycle and techno-economic analyses to confirm net removal of CO2.

program: Precommercial Direct Air Capture Technology Prize Competitions
summary: This investment supports advance research, development, demonstration, and commercial application of direct air capture technologies. Prizes will be awarded to projects that achieve breakthrough innovation in DAC technologies.

This program aims to preserve the existing U.S. reactor fleet and save thousands of high-paying jobs across the country. Under the new program, owners or operators of commercial U.S. reactors can apply for certification to bid on credits to support their continued operations.

program: Preventing Outages and Enhancing the Resilience of the Electric Grid / Hazard Hardening
summary: This program aims to strengthen and modernize America’s power grid against wildfires, extreme weather, and other natural disasters. FY2024 funding will support awards for competitive grants for industry and formula grants for states, territories, and American Indian Tribes.

program: Smart Grid Investment Matching Grant Program
summary: This program promotes a broader suite of grid enhancing technologies that will increase the capacity of the existing transmission system; prevent faults that may lead to wildfires or other system disturbances; integrate ever increasing-renewable resources; and deploy technologies that are better able monitor and analyze the impact of transportation and building electrification on the grid.
This program will facilitate the construction of electric power transmission lines and related facilities to enable greater clean energy growth and provide low-cost clean energy to more Americans.

This program provides incentive payments to enhance existing hydropower facilities through capital improvements directly related to three main areas: grid resiliency, dam safety, and environmental improvements.

program: Assisting Federal Facilities with Energy Conservation Technologies (AFFECT) Grant Program
summary: This program program aims to drive decarbonization of the Federal building stock and fleet electrification and optimize energy and water management systems.

This program provides incentive payments for electric energy generated and sold by a qualified hydroelectric facility during the incentive period, to the owner or authorized operator of such a facility.
This program provides incentive payments to owners or operators of existing hydroelectric facilities for capital improvements that can increase efficiency of a hydroelectric facility by at least 3%.

This program aims to catalyze high-impact, large-scale, transformational advanced industrial facilities to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in energy-intensive industrial subsectors. OCED will support large-scale overhauls for existing facilities, common technologies across multiple facilities, or full facility builds that tie to or replace existing energy-intensive industrial facilities as well as upgrades and retrofits that target decarbonization within a unit operation or process line at an existing industrial facility.

suboffice: Title 17 Innovative Technology Loan Guarantee Program
program: Title 17 Innovative Technology Loan Guarantee Program - Credit Subsidy
summary: This program aims to support issuance of new loan guarantees to projects that either were already eligible under section 1703 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 or will become eligible due to the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) that expanded eligible activities to support projects involving critical minerals processing, manufacturing, and recycling.

suboffice: Energy Infrastructure Reinvestment Loan Guarantee Program
program: Energy Infrastructure Reinvestment Loan Guarantee Program - Credit Subsidy
summary: This program aims to support issuance of new loan guarantees under the Energy Infrastructure Reinvestment Program (section 1706) created by the IRA to help retool, repower, repurpose, or replace energy infrastructure that has ceased operations or to improve the efficiency of infrastructure that is currently operating.

suboffice: Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing Loan Program
program: Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing Loan Program - Credit Subsidy
summary: This program aims to issue loans for a range of advanced technology vehicles and their components, including newly authorized uses from the IIJA, which to date had not been funded. Expanded uses include medium- and heavy-duty vehicles, locomotives, maritime vessels including offshore wind vessels, aviation, and hyperloop. The IRA removed the statutory limitation on direct loan authority and provided $3 billion of additional appropriations, including $2.975 billion in credit subsidy.

program: Tribal Energy Loan Guarantee Program - Credit Subsidy
summary: This program provides direct loans or partial loan guarantees to federally recognized tribes, including Alaska Native village or regional or village corporations; or a Tribal Energy Development Organization that is wholly or substantially owned by a federally recognized Indian tribe or Alaska Native Corporation. In addition to the access to existing partial loan guarantees, the IRA provided permanent access to eligible borrowers to direct loans through the U.S. Treasury’s Federal Financing Bank (FFB).

program: Home Energy Performance-Based, Whole House Rebates
summary: This programs aims to award grants that will assist State energy offices in the implementation of a rebate program that encourages whole-house energy saving home energy retrofits by homeowners and other eligible entities.

program: High-Efficiency Electric Home Rebate Program - State Energy Office Grants
summary: This program aims to award grants to state energy offices to develop and implement a high-efficiency electric home rebate program. A state energy office may use up to 20 percent of the grant amount for planning, administration, or technical assistance. The remaining funds are for rebates for the purchase of high-efficiency electric home appliances.

program: High-Efficiency Electric Home Rebate Program - Indian Tribes Grants
summary: This program aims to award grants to Tribal entities to develop and implement a high-efficiency electric home rebate program. An Indian Tribe may use up to 20 percent of the grant amount for planning, administration, or technical assistance. The remaining funds are for rebates for the purchase of high-efficiency electric home appliances.

program: State-Based Home Efficiency Contractor Training Grants
summary: This program provides financial assistance to States to develop and implement training and education to contractors involved in the installation of home energy efficiency and electrification improvements.

program: Assistance for Latest Building Energy Code Adoption
summary: This program assists States and units of local government to upgrade their residential and commercial building energy codes.

program: Assistance for Zero Energy Code Adoption
summary: This program assists States and units of local government to adopt “zero” building energy codes for residential and commercial buildings.

program: Enhanced Use of Defense Production Act (DPA) of 1950
summary: This program focuses on heat pumps and will invest in manufacturers with domestic operations to retool existing factories or build new factories for heat pumps and their components. These investments will bolster U.S. competitiveness and security while reducing reliance among U.S. consumers and businesses on volatile natural gas and home heating oil costs and supply.

This program provides grants for domestic production of efficient hybrid, plug-in electric hybrid, plug-in electric drive, and hydrogen fuel cell electric vehicles, in accordance with section 712 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005.

This program provides $14,000,000 to the Material Plasma Exposure eXperiment (MPEX) project which is being utilized to complete the MPEX Facility Enhancements scope, which will be completed in January 2024. At the time of the IRA funding, the MPEX Facility Enhancements represented the critical path for the project. This funding has allowed the project to proceed more quickly, reducing risk and completing critical project scope as early as possible.

program: Matter in Extreme Conditions (MEC) Petawatt Upgrade, SLAC
summary: This program aids to advance the preliminary design package in support of pursuing Critical Decision (CD)‐2 (Approve Performance Baseline) currently planned for FY 2025. This funding will also allow the project team to develop a more thorough plan to proceed through CD‐3 (Approve Start of Construction) and project execution.

This program provides $66,000,000 for Cash Contributions to fulfill U.S. agreements to the ITER Organization from previous underfunding. The remaining $190,000,000 will continue to be used to significantly enhance the design and fabrication performance of project scope in FY 2023–2024 to include the funding activities associated with the Central Solenoid Module fabrication and shipment process and the design, fabrication, and delivery of Tokomak Cooling Water System components.

program: Section 45: Credit for Electricity Produced from Certain Renewable Sources (PTC)
summary: This incentive modifies the credit for production of electricity from renewable sources by extending it for projects beginning construction before January 1, 2025 and modified to tie the value of the credit to meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. Eligible recipients include facilities generating electricity from wind, biomass, geothermal, solar, small irrigation, landfill and trash, hydropower, and marine and hydrokinetic renewable energy. The Base credit is 0.3 cents/kW, inflation adjusted. The Bonus credit is increased by 5 times for projects meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. Credit is increased by 10% if the project meets certain domestic content requirements for steel, iron, and manufactured products. Credit is increased by 10% if located in an energy community. This credit has both direct pay eligiblity and transferability.

This incentive modifies the credit for the investment in renewable energy projects, extended to projects beginning construction before January 1, 2025 and includes standalone energy storage with capacity of at least 5 kWh, biogas, microgrid controllers (20MW or less), and interconnection property for small projects (5MW or less). The value of the credit is tied to prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. Eligible recipients includes fuel cell, solar, geothermal, small wind, energy storage, biogas, microgrid controllers, and combined heat and power properties. For solar, the credit includes both the equipment that uses solar energy to generate electricity, to heat or cool (or provide hot water for use in) a structure, or to provide solar process heat, and the equipment that uses solar energy to illuminate the inside of a structure using fiber-optic distributed sunlight or electrochromic glass that uses electricity to change its light transmittance properties in order to heat or cool a structure. The Base credit amount is 6% of qualified investment (basis of energy property). For geothermal heat property, the base investment tax credit is 6% for the first 10 years, scaling down to 5.2% in 2033 and 4.4% in 2034. The Bonus credit is 5 times the base amount for projects meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. The credit is increased by up to 10 percentage points for projects meeting certain domestic content requirements for steel, iron, and manufactured products. The credit is increased by up to 10 percentage points if located in an energy community. The credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability.

This incentive modifies the credit for carbon dioxide sequestration coupled with permitted end uses within the U.S. by extending it, tying the credit amounts to meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements, providing an enhanced credit for direct air capture (DAC), and lowering the carbon capture threshold requirements at facilities. The credit can be claimed for 12 years after a facility is placed in service. Facilities must be placed in service before 1/1/33. Eligible recipients are U.S. facilities within minimum volumes: 1,000 metric tons of CO2 per year for DAC facilities; 18,750 metric tons for electricity generating facilities (with carbon capture capacity of 75% of baseline CO2 production); 12,500 metric tons for other facilities. The Base credit amount is $17/metric ton of carbon dioxide captured and sequestered; $12/metric ton for carbon dioxide that is injected for enhanced oil recovery or utilized. Those amounts are $36 and $26, respectively, for direct air capture facilities. The Bonus credit is 5 times the base amounts if the facility meets prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. This credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability.

program: Section 45U: Zero-Emission Nuclear Power Production Credit
summary: This incentive creates a new tax credit for electricity produced at a qualified nuclear power facility. The credit is available for electricity produced and sold after December 31, 2023. Not available for tax years beginning after December 31, 2032. Eligible recipients include existing nuclear power plants at time of enactment that are not eligible for the 45J credit (advanced nuclear production tax credit). The Base credit amount is 0.3 cents/kWh, inflation adjusted after 2024. The Credit amount phases down depending on the amount of energy produced and the gross receipts of the nuclear power facility. The Bonuse credit is 5 times the base credit if prevailing wage requirement is met for workers doing alteration or repair at the facility. This credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability. Facilities eligible for the 45J advanced nuclear production tax credit are not eligible for the 45U credit. Payments from federal, state, or local zero-emission nuclear subsidies reduce the credit amount.

program: Section 40A: Incentives for Biodiesel, Renewable Diesel and Alternative Fuels Credit
summary: This incentive was originally set to expire on December 31, 2022, but has been extended through December 31, 2024 by the IRA. Base credit amount is $1.00 per gallon for biodiesel, biodiesel mixtures, and renewable diesel; $0.50 per gallon for alternative fuels and alternative fuel mixes. Additional $0.10 credit for small agri-diesel producers. In addition, there is a $1.00-per-gallon excise tax credit for biodiesel and renewable diesel mixtures. No direct pay eligibility nor transferability for this credit.

This incentive was originally set to expire on December 31, 2021, but has been extended through December 31, 2024 by the IRA. A second generation biofuel producer that is registered with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) may be eligible for a tax incentive in the amount of up to $1.01 per gallon of second generation biofuel that is: sold and used by the purchaser in the purchaser's trade or business to produce a second generation biofuel mixture; sold and used by the purchaser as a fuel in a trade or business; sold at retail for use as a motor vehicle fuel; used by the producer in a trade or business to produce a second generation biofuel mixture; or used by the producer as a fuel in a trade or business. No direct pay eligibility nor transferability for this credit.

This incentive establishes a new credit for sustainable aviation fuel mixtures sold or used after December 31, 2022 through December 31, 2024. Provides a tax credit for the sale or use of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) that achieves a lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions reduction of at least 50% as compared with petroleum-based jet fuel. Eligible recipients are producers and blenders of SAF-kerosene fuel mixtures for aviation. Qualified SAF mixture must be made in the United States, and fueling of the aircraft must occur in the United States. The Base credit amount is $1.25/gallon of SAF. The Bonus credit amount is up to $0.50/gallon depending on lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions of SAF relative to petroleum-based jet fuel. There is no direct pay eligibility nor transferability for this credit.

This incentive creates a new credit for the production of clean hydrogen at a qualified clean hydrogen production facility (the existing excise tax for liquified hydrogen terminated after December 31, 2022). Qualified clean hydrogen means hydrogen that is produced through a process that results in a lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions rate of not greater than 4 kilograms of CO2e per kilogram of hydrogen. The hydrogen must be produced in the United States or a possession of the United States in the ordinary course of a trade or business of the taxpayer for sale or use. The credit is for hydrogen produced after December 31, 2022, and available for facilities placed in service before January 1, 2033 for their first 10 years in service. The Base credit amount is $0.60/kg multiplied by the applicable percentage. The applicable percentage ranges from 20% to 100% depending on lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions. The $0.60/kg is adjusted for inflation. The Bonus credit is 5 times the base credit if the facility meets prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. The credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability. Taxpayers can make an irrevocable election to choose the ITC in lieu of the 45V credit as long as they have not claimed the 45Q credit for carbon sequestration.

program: Section 25C: Energy Efficient Home Improvement Credit
summary: This incentive modifies the credit for energy-efficiency improvements of residential homes. Eligibility and standards are modified including credit rate is increased from 10% to 30% and the $500/per taxpayer lifetime limit is eliminated and replaced with increased annual limits. The period of availability for the credit is 2022 through 2032. Eligible recipients are homeowners and renters for certain improvements. The Base credit amount is 30% of cost, with limits for each type of improvement and total per year. Credit capped at $600 for “energy property,” e.g. efficient heating and cooling equipment; $600 for windows; $250 per door, $500 total for doors; $2,000 for heat pumps; $1,200 for qualified energy efficiency improvements to the building envelope, including insulation and air sealing. Total annual credit capped at $1,200, with a separate annual $2,000 limit for heat pumps. $150 credit for home energy audits. There is no Bonus credit. There is no direct pay eligibility nor transferability.

This incentive modifies the credit for the purchase of residential clean energy equipment (solar electric panels, solar water heaters, wind turbines, geothermal heat pumps, fuel cells, and now including battery storage with capacity of at least 3 kWh). The credit is extended at 30% from 2022 through 2032, with a phasedown through 2034. Battery storage is newly eligible in 2023 and the biomass fuel propery credit is eliminated. The Base credit is 30% of cost of equipment through 2032; 26% in 2033; 22% in 2034. There is no Bonus credit. This credit has no direct pay eligibility nor transferability.

program: Section 179D: Energy Efficient Commercial Buildings Deduction
summary: This incentive modifies the tax deduction for energy efficiency improvements to commercial buildings, such as improvements to interior lighting; heating, cooling, ventilation, and hot water; and building envelope. The deduction is permanent with new rules beginning in 2023. Eligible recipients of the deduction include owners and long-term lessees of commercial buildings, designers of energy efficient building property (architects, engineers) and tax-exempt owners of commercial properties, pending Treasury guidance on deduction allocation. The Base credit amount is $0.50-$1 per square foot, depending on increase in efficiency, with deduction over four year periods capped at $1 per square foot. Inflation adjusted. Alternatively, taxpayers can deduct adjusted basis in “qualified retrofit plans” that reduce a building’s energy use intensity by at least 25%. The Bonus credit is 5 times the base amount if the project meets prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. There s neither direct pay eligibility nor transferability for this credit.

program: Section 45L: Construction of Energy-efficient New Homes credit
summary: This incentive modifies the credit for construction of new energy efficient homes, retroactively extending the credit that previously expired at the end of 2021 with new rules effective for homes acquired after 2022. The Base credit is $2,500 for new homes meeting Energy Star standards; $5,000 for certified zero-energy ready homes. For multifamily, base amounts are $500 per unit for Energy Star and $1000 per unit for zero-energy ready. The Bonus credit for multifamily home is 5 times the base amount if prevailing wage requirements are met. There is no direct pay eligiblity nor transferability. Taxpayers claiming the Low-Income Housing Tax Credit do not have to reduce basis for 45L credits claimed.

This incentive modifies the credit for purchasers of qualifying clean vehicles, including battery electric, plug-in hybrid, or fuel cell electric vehicles. To qualify for the maximum $7,500 credit, the vehicle must meet certain standards for North American assembly; the battery’s components must meet certain standards for manufacturing or assembly; and the battery’s critical minerals must meet certain requirements for sourcing or processing in the US or from trusted trade partners (referenced in more detail below). The credit is generally available for vehicles placed in service between 2023-2032. The tax credit is not available for consumers who have adjusted gross incomes for the current or preceding year above $300,000 (couples), $225,000 (heads of household), $150,000 (singles). Not inflation adjusted. The Base credit amount is $0. The Bonus credit starts at $3,750 for vehicles meeting critical minerals requirement. The vehicle must contain a threshold percentage of critical minerals extracted or processed in the United States or in a country with which the US has a free trade agreement, or recycled in North America. Additional $3,750 credit for vehicles meeting the requirement that a threshold percentage of battery components be manufactured or assembled in North America. Vehicles must meet other requirements for credit, including final assembly in North America and MSRP limits (generally $55,000; for vans, SUVs, and pickups $80,000). Starting in 2024, qualifying vehicles cannot have battery components manufactured or assembled by a foreign entity of concern. Starting in 2025, qualifying vehicles’ batteries cannot contain critical minerals extracted, processed, or recycled by a foreign entity of concern. There is no direct pay eligibility but starting in 2024, consumers can transfer credits only to the dealer at point of sale under Section 30D(g). You cannot claim both Section 30D and Section 45W (Qualified Commercial Clean Vehicles credit).

program: Section 25E: Previously Owned Plug-in Electric Vehicles credit
summary: This incentive creates a new credit for purchasers of pre-owned clean vehicles, placed in service between 2023-2032. The credit is not available for consumers who have adjusted gross incomes for the current or preceding year above $150,000 (couples), $112,500 (heads of household), $75,000 (singles). Individuals can claim only once per three years. Vehicles must be sold by a dealer; the sale price must be $25,000 or less; and it can only be claimed once per vehicle. The base credit amount is the lessrer of $4,000 or 30% of sale price. There is no bonus credit. There is no direct pay eligibility but starting in 2024, consumers can transfer credits only to the dealer at point of sale under section 25(f).

program: Section 45W: Qualified Commercial Clean Vehicles Credit
summary: This incentive creates a new credit for purchasers of qualified commercial clean vehicles, placed in service after January 1, 2023 and acquired before January 1, 2033. Eligible recipients are businesses that acquire motor vehicles or mobile machinery for use or lease; tax-exempt entities that acquire them for use. The Base credit amount is the lesser of either 15% of the vehicle’s basis (i.e. its cost to the purchaser) or 30% for vehicles without internal combustion engines, or the amount the purchase price exceeds the price of a comparable internal combustion vehicle. The credit is capped at $7,500 for vehicles < 14,000 lbs and $40,000 for all other clean vehicles. There is no bonus credit. This credit has direct pay eligibility but does not have transferability. You cannot claim both Section 30D (Clean Vehicle Credit) and Section 45W credit.

program: Section 30C: Alternative Fuel Vehicle Refueling Property Credit
summary: This incentive modifies the credit for alternative fuel vehicle refueling and charging property in low-income and rural areas. The credit is extended to include prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements for businesses claiming the credit. It also adds bidirectional charging equipment, charging equipment for 2- and 3-wheel electric vehicles. The credit is available from January 1, 2023 through December 31, 2032. Eligible refuleing property must be for clean-burning fuels (include electricity, ethanol, natural gas, hydrogen, biodiesel, and others) and must be located in low-income and non-urban (rural) areas. The Base credit is 6% of the cost for businesses, limited to a $100,000 credit per item of property for businesses. 30% for individuals, limited to $1,000. The Bonus credit is that businesses can claim a 30% credit for projects meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. The credit has direct pay eligibility and transferability for propoerty used in a trade or business.

This incentive modifies the credit for investments in advanced energy projects. Section 48C has been enacted since 2009 but was fully allocated after the 2nd allocation round in 2013. The IRA provides the Secretary of Treasury with new authority to allocate $10 billion to projects that (1) re-equip, expand, or establish an industrial or manufacturing facility for the production or recycling of a range of renewable energy and energy efficiency equipment, carbon capture equipment, and advanced vehicles; (2) re-equip an industrial or manufacturing facility with equipment designed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 20 percent; or (3) re-equip, expand, or establish an industrial facility for the processing, refining, or recycling of critical materials. IRA requires the Secretary of the Treasury to set aside 40 percent of the qualified investments ($4 billion) for projects in energy communities where a coal mine or coal-fired electric generating unit has closed. The credit is available when the application and certification process begins and ends when the credits are fully allocated. The Base credit amount is 6% of taxpayer's qualifying investment. The Bonus credit is businesses can claim a 30% credit for projects meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. The credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability. You cannot claim the Section 45X (Advanced Manufacturing Production credit) for property produced at facilities that received the Section 48C credit.

This incentive creates a new production tax credit for domestic manufacturing of components along the supply chain for solar modules, wind turbines, inverters, battery components, and critical minerals. The credit for critical minerals is permanent starting in 2023. For other items, the full credit is available between 2023-2029 and phases down over 2030-2032. Eligible recipients are domestic manufacturers. The Base credit amount varies by technology and there is no bonus credit. The credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability. You cannot claim the Section 45X credit for property produced at facilities that received the Section 48C (Advanced Energy Project credit).

This incentive creates a new technology-neutral tax credit for production of clean electricity. It replaces the Section 45 PTC extended through 2024. This credit is made available to facilities placed in service after December 31, 2024. Phase-out starts the later of either 2032 or when U.S. greenhouse gas emissions from electricity are 25% of 2022 emissions or lower. Eligible recipients include facilities generating electricity for which the greenhouse gas emissions rate is not greater than zero. The Base credit is 0.3 cents/kW, inflation adjusted. The Bonus credit is increased by 5 times for projects meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. Credit is increased by 10% for projects meeting certain domestic content requirements for steel, iron, and manufactured products. Credit is increased by 10% if located in an energy community. This credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability.

This incentive creates a new technology-neutral tax credit for investment in facilities that generate clean electricity. It replaces the Section 48 ITC extended through 2024. This credit is made available to facilities placed in service after December 31, 2024. Phase-out starts the later of 2032 or when U.S. greenhouse gas emissions from electricity are 25% of 2022 emissions or lower. Eligible recipients are facilities that generate electricity with a greenhouse gas emissions rate that is not greater than zero and qualified energy storage technologies. The Base credit amount is 6% of qualified investment. The Bonus credit is increased by 5 times for facilities meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. Credit is increased by up to 10 percentage points for facilities meeting certain domestic content requirements for steel, iron, and manufactured products. Credit is increased by up to 10 percentage points if located in an energy community. This credit has both direct pay eligibility and transferability.

program: Cost Recovery for Qualified Facilities, Qualified Property, and Energy Storage Technology
summary: Section 13703 offers an additional tax deduction for facilities or property qualifying for Section 45Y and 48E credits. These facilities or property will be treated as a 5-year Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS) property for purposes of cost recovery; meaning, they will be able to deduct from their taxable income the depreciating value of their business assets, such as equipment, faster than the value actually declines. This tax deduction applies to facilities and property placed in service after December 31, 2024. In practical terms, qualifying facilities or property will be able to take bigger deductions—leaving them with lower taxable income—in the earlier years of a clean energy investment.

This incentive creates a new tax credit for domestic production of clean transportation fuels, including sustainable aviation fuels, that are produced after December 31, 2024 and used or sold before December 31, 2027. Eligible recipients are registered producers in the United States. Fuels with less than 50 kilograms of carbon dioxide equivalent per million British thermal units (CO2e per mmBTU) qualify as clean fuels eligible for credits. The base credit amount is $0.20/gallon for non-aviation fuel and $0.35/gallon for aviation fuel, multiplied by the carbon dioxide “emissions factor” of the fuel. Inflation adjusted after 2024. The bonuse credit is 5 times the base amount ($1/gallon for non-aviation fuel, $1.75 gallon for aviation fuel, multiplied by the emissions factor) for facilities meeting prevailing wage and registered apprenticeship requirements. Inflation adjusted after 2024. There is both direct pay eligibility and transferability for this credit.

suboffice: Office of Transportation and Air Quality (OTAQ)
summary: Program provides funding to offset the costs of replacing heavy-duty Class 6 and 7 commercial vehicles with zero-emission vehicles; deploying infrastructure needed to charge, fuel, or maintain these zero-emission vehicles; and developing and training the necessary workforce. Program covers up to 100 percent of costs for (1) incremental cost of replacing an existing heavy-duty vehicle with a zero-emission vehicle; (2) purchasing and operating associated infrastructure; (3) workforce development and training; (4) planning and technical activities.

suboffice: Office of Transportation and Air Quality (OTAQ)
program: Grants to Reduce Air Pollution at Ports
summary:
Program to purchase and install zero-emission port equipment and technology, conduct associated planning or permitting activities for this equipment and technology, and develop climate action plans to further address air pollution at ports. Eligible uses include: (1) To purchase or install zero-emission port equipment or technology for use at, or to directly serve, one or more ports; (2) To conduct any relevant planning or permitting in connection with the purchase or installation of such zero-emission port equipment or technology; and (3) To develop qualified climate action plans

Eligible uses include: (1) To purchase or install zero-emission port equipment or technology for use at, or to directly serve, one or more ports; (2) To conduct any relevant planning or permitting in connection with the purchase or installation of such zero-emission port equipment or technology; and (3) To develop qualified climate action plans.

suboffice: Office of the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund
program: Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund - Solar for All Program
summary:
Program to provide up to 60 grants to States, Tribal governments, municipalities, and nonprofits to expand the number of low-income and disadvantaged communities that are primed for residential and community solar investment—enabling millions of families to access affordable, resilient, and clean solar energy.

Eligible uses: Grantees will use grant funds to expand existing low-income solar programs or design and deploy new Solar for All programs.

suboffice: Office of the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund
program: Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund - National Clean Investment Fund
summary:
Program to fund two to three national nonprofits that will partner with private capital providers to deliver financing at scale to businesses, communities, community lenders, and others, catalyzing tens of thousands of clean technology projects to accelerate our progress towards energy independence and a net-zero economic future.

Eligible uses include financial products and supporting predevelopment expenditures to qualified projects, implementing Section 134(b)(1) that authorizes funding for “direct investments.”

suboffice: Office of the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund
program: Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund - Clean Communities Investment Accelerator
summary:
Program to fund two to seven hub nonprofits with the plans and capabilities to rapidly build the clean financing capacity of specific networks of public, quasi-public and non-profit community lenders—including community development financial institutions (including Native CDFIs), credit unions, green banks, housing finance agencies, and minority depository institutions—to ensure that households, small businesses, schools, and community institutions in low-income and disadvantaged communities have access to financing for cost-saving and pollution-reducing clean technology projects.

Grantees will support community lenders, which in turn support deployment of qualified projects within three broad categories: distributed power generation and storage; decarbonization retrofits of existing buildings; and transportation pollution reduction.

suboffice: Office of Transportation and Air Quality (OTAQ)
summary: Program to identify and reduce diesel emissions resulting from goods movement facilities and vehicles servicing goods movement facilities in low-income and disadvantaged communities to address the health impacts of such emissions on such communities.

suboffice: Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards
program: Funding to Address Air Pollution at Schools
summary:
Program to provide funding for grants and other activities to monitor and reduce pollution and greenhouse gas emissions at schools in low-income and disadvantaged communities. To provide technical assistance to schools in low-income and disadvantaged communities to develop school air and environmental quality plans and to identify and mitigate ongoing air pollution hazards.

Eligible uses include: (1) To address environmental issues affecting air quality in schools; (2) To develop school air and environmental quality plans that include standards for school building, design, construction, or renovation; (3) To identify and mitigate ongoing air pollution hazards in schools; (4) To provide technical assistance addressing air quality to schools in low-income and disadvantaged communities.

Program to provide funding for EPA to do a variety of activities related to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from electricity generation and use, including (1) for consumer-related education and partnerships; (2) for education, technical assistance, and partnerships within low- income and disadvantaged communities; (3) for industry-related outreach, technical assistance, and partnerships; (4) for outreach and technical assistance to, and partnerships with, state, Tribal, and local governments; (5) to assess the reductions in greenhouse gas emissions that result from changes in domestic electricity generation and use that are anticipated to occur on an annual basis through fiscal year 2031; (6) to ensure that reductions in greenhouse gas emissions are achieved through use of the existing authorities of the Clean Air Act, incorporating the assessment described in (5). 

Eligible uses include: (1) To address environmental issues affecting air quality in schools; (2) To develop school air and environmental quality plans that include standards for school building, design, construction, or renovation; (3) To identify and mitigate ongoing air pollution hazards in schools; (4) To provide technical assistance addressing air quality to schools in low-income and disadvantaged communities.

suboffice: Office of Air Quality Planning and Standards
program: Funding for Section 211(o) of the Clean Air Act
summary:
Program to support investments in advanced biofuels and to implement the Renewable Fuel Standard, including developing tests and protocols regarding effects of fuel and fuel additives; to update analyses of lifecycle greenhouse gases of a fuel; to review impacts of transportation fuels on the general public and on low-income and disadvantaged communities; to award grants to industry and other related activities to support investments in advanced biofuels.

Eligible uses include to develop tests and protocols regarding effects of fuel and fuel additives; to update analyses of lifecycle greenhouse gases of a fuel; to review impacts of transportation fuels on the general public and on low-income and disadvantaged communities; to award grants to industry and other related activities to support investments in advanced biofuels.

program: Implementation of the American Innovation and Manufacturing Act
summary:
Program to fund EPA’s implementation of the American Innovation and Manufacturing Act, a bipartisan law to phase down the production and consumption of listed hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), maximize reclamation and minimize releases from equipment, and facilitate the transition to next-generation technologies through sector-based restrictions.

Eligible uses are: (1) Provide funding for EPA for AIM Act implementation to carry out subsections (a) through (i) and subsection (k) of the statute; (2) To deploy new implementation and compliance tools to carry out subsections (a) through (i) and subsection (k) of the statute; (3) For competitive grants for reclaim and innovative destruction technologies under subsections (a) through (i) and subsection (k) of the statute.

Program to provide funding for EPA to improve standardization and transparency of corporate climate action commitments and plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions; to support corporate progress toward meeting such commitments and implementing such plans; and to enhance transparency regarding corporate progress.

administration: Office of Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention
suboffice: Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics
summary: Program to support the development and standardization of environmental product declarations, including measurements of the embodied greenhouse gas emissions of construction materials and products. Eligible uses are developing and verifying environmental product declarations; technical assistance; other activities that assist in measuring, reporting, and steadily reducing the quantity of embodied carbon in construction materials and products.

administration: Office of Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention
suboffice: Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics
summary: Program to support the development and standardization of environmental product declarations, including measurements of the embodied greenhouse gas emissions of construction materials and products. Eligible uses are developing and verifying environmental product declarations; technical assistance; other activities that assist in measuring, reporting, and steadily reducing the quantity of embodied carbon in construction materials and products.

Program to provide financial and technical assistance for preparing and submitting greenhouse gas reports, monitoring methane emissions, and reducing methane and other greenhouse gas emissions from petroleum and natural gas systems, including improving and deploying equipment to reduce emissions, supporting innovation, permanently shutting in and plugging wells, mitigating health effects in low-income and disadvantaged communities, improving climate resiliency, and supporting environmental restoration. The statute also establishes a waste emissions charge for applicable facilities that report more than 25,000 metric tons of CO2 equivalent per year (to the petroleum and natural gas systems source category of the Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program) and that exceed statutorily specified waste emissions thresholds.

Eligible uses include to provide funding for financial and technical assistance for preparing and submitting greenhouse gas reports, monitoring methane emissions, and reducing methane and other greenhouse gas emissions from petroleum and natural gas systems, including improving and deploying equipment to reduce emissions, supporting innovation, permanently shutting in and plugging wells, mitigating health effects in low-income and disadvantaged communities, improving climate resiliency, and supporting environmental restoration.

program: Climate Pollution Reduction Grants: Planning Grants
summary: Program to provide grants to Tribes, states, air pollution control agencies, and local governments to develop and implement plans for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The statute allocates $250 million for planning grants and $4.750 billion for implementation grants.

program: Climate Pollution Reduction Grants: Implementation Grants
summary: Program to provide grants to Tribes, states, air pollution control agencies, and local governments to develop and implement plans for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The statute allocates $250 million for planning grants and $4.750 billion for implementation grants.

administration: Office of Chemical Safety and Pollution Prevention
suboffice: Office of Pollution Prevention and Toxics
program: Low Embodied Carbon Labeling for Construction Materials
summary: Program to develop and carry out a program to identify and label construction materials and products that have substantially lower levels of embodied greenhouse gas emissions. EPA exploring both non-competitive formula funding and competitive grants.

This investment will promote the safe handling of used batteries and improve battery recycling programs. Establishes a program to promote battery recycling through the development of voluntary labeling guidelines for batteries and other forms of communication materials for battery producers and consumers about the reuse and recycling of critical materials from batteries. The purposes of the program are to improve battery collection and reduce battery waste, including by identifying battery collection locations and increasing accessibility to those locations; promoting consumer education about battery collection and recycling; and reducing safety concerns relating to the improper disposal of batteries.

This investment will promote the safe handling of used batteries and improve battery recycling programs. The Environmental Protection Agency will develop best practices that may be implemented by State, Tribal, and local governments with respect to the collection of batteries to be recycled in a manner that to the maximum extent practicable, is technically and economically feasible for State, Tribal, and local governments; is environmentally sound and safe for waste management workers; and optimizes the value and use of material derived from recycling of batteries. The Environmental Protection Agency will develop the best practices in coordination with State, Tribal, and local governments and relevant nongovernmental and private sector entities. 

Eligible uses: The Administrator shall develop best practices that may be implemented by State, Tribal, and local governments with respect to the collection of batteries to be recycled in a manner that to the maximum extent practicable, is technically and economically feasible for State, Tribal, and local governments; is environmentally sound and safe for waste management workers; and optimizes the value and use of material derived from recycling of batteries.

The Environmental Protection Agency will develop best practices that may be implemented by State, Tribal, and local governments with respect to the collection of batteries to be recycled in a manner that to the maximum extent practicable, is technically and economically feasible for State, Tribal, and local governments; is environmentally sound and safe for waste management workers; and optimizes the value and use of material derived from recycling of batteries. The Environmental Protection Agency will develop the best practices in coordination with State, Tribal, and local governments and relevant nongovernmental and private sector entities. 

Eligible uses: The Administrator shall develop best practices that may be implemented by State, Tribal, and local governments with respect to the collection of batteries to be recycled in a manner that to the maximum extent practicable, is technically and economically feasible for State, Tribal, and local governments; is environmentally sound and safe for waste management workers; and optimizes the value and use of material derived from recycling of batteries.

State or local governments, eligible contractors, and nonprofit school transportation associations are authorized to receive grant funds. Fifty percent of the funds are authorized for zero-emission school buses, and fifty percent of the funds are authorized for alternative fuels and zero-emission school buses. Funds may be prioritized for rural or low-income communities and entities that have matching funds
available. 

Eligible uses: State or local governments, eligible contractors, and nonprofit school transportation associations are authorized to receive grant funds. Fifty percent of the funds are authorized for zero emission school buses, and fifty percent of the funds are authorized for alternative fuels and zero-emission school buses. Funds may be prioritized for rural or low-income communities and entities that have matching funds available.

State or local governments, eligible contractors, and nonprofit school transportation associations are authorized to receive grant funds. Fifty percent of the funds are authorized for zero-emission school buses, and fifty percent of the funds are authorized for alternative fuels and zero-emission school buses. Funds may be prioritized for rural or low-income communities and entities that have matching funds
available. 

Eligible uses: State or local governments, eligible contractors, and nonprofit school transportation associations are authorized to receive grant funds. Fifty percent of the funds are authorized for zero emission school buses, and fifty percent of the funds are authorized for alternative fuels and zero-emission school buses. Funds may be prioritized for rural or low-income communities and entities that have matching funds available.

administration: Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights
program: Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grants
summary:
Program to provide grants and technical assistance to community-based non-profit organizations, alone or in certain partnerships, including those with Indian Tribes, to reduce indoor and outdoor air pollution, including greenhouse gases; monitor for pollution; improve community resilience to the impacts of climate change, including extreme heat and wildfire; and build the capacity of disadvantaged communities to engage with state and federal decision-making processes. EPA is appropriated $2.8 billion for financial assistance, and $200 million for technical assistance up until September 30, 2026.

Eligible uses include: (1) Community-led air and other pollution monitoring, prevention, and remediation, and investments in low- and zero-emission and resilient technologies and related infrastructure and workforce development that help reduce greenhouse gas emissions and other air pollutants; (2) Mitigating climate and health risks from urban heat islands, extreme heat, wood heater emissions, and wildfire events; (3) Climate resiliency and adaptation; (4) Reducing indoor toxics and indoor air pollution; or (5) Facilitating engagement of disadvantaged communities in state and federal advisory groups, workshops, rulemakings, and other public processes.

administration: Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights
program: Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grants: Environmental Justice Collaborative Problem-Solving (EJCPS) Cooperative Agreement Program
summary: Program to assist recipients in building collaborative partnerships to help them understand and address environmental and public health concerns in their communities. Eligible uses are: (1) Community-led air and other pollution monitoring, prevention, and remediation, and investments in low- and zero-emission and resilient technologies and related infrastructure and workforce development that help reduce greenhouse gas emissions and other air pollutants; (2) Mitigating climate and health risks from urban heat islands, extreme heat, wood heater emissions, and wildfire events; (3) Climate resiliency and adaptation; (4) Reducing indoor toxics and indoor air pollution; or (5) Facilitating engagement of disadvantaged communities in state and federal advisory groups, workshops, rulemakings, and other public processes. The funding mechanism is cooperative agreements funded for a three-year performance period.

administration: Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights
program: Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grants: Environmental Justice Collaborative Problem-Solving (EJCPS) Cooperative Agreement Program

administration: Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights
program: Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grants: Environmental Justice Thriving Communities Grantmaking Program
summary: Program to fund up to 11 "pass-through" entities to serve as grantmakers, via subawards, to community-based nonprofit organizations, underserved and disadvantaged communities, and other stakeholders in communities with environmental justice concerns. The funding mechanism is cooperative agreements for a three-year performance period.

administration: Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights
program: Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grants: Environmental Justice Thriving Communities Grantmaking Program
summary:
Program to fund up to 11 "pass-through" entities to serve as grantmakers, via subawards, to community-based nonprofit organizations, underserved and disadvantaged communities, and other stakeholders in communities with environmental justice concerns.

The funding mechanism is cooperative agreements for a three-year performance period.

administration: Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights
program: Environmental and Climate Justice Block Grants: The Environmental Justice Government-to-Government (EJG2G) Program
summary:
Program to provide funding to governmental entities at the state, local, territorial and tribal level to support and/or create model government activities that lead to measurable environmental or public health results in communities disproportionately burdened by environmental harms and risks.o provide funding to governmental entities at the state, local, territorial and tribal level to support and/or create model government activities that lead to measurable environmental or public health results in communities disproportionately burdened by environmental harms and risks.

Eligible uses are (1) Community-led air and other pollution monitoring, prevention, and remediation, and investments in low- and zero-emission and resilient technologies and related infrastructure and workforce development that help reduce greenhouse gas emissions and other air pollutants; (2) Mitigating climate and health risks from urban heat islands, extreme heat, wood heater emissions, and wildfire events; (3) Climate resiliency and adaptation; (4) Reducing indoor toxics and indoor air pollution; or (5) Facilitating engagement of disadvantaged communities in state and federal advisory groups, workshops, rulemakings, and other public processes.
